title: Tuesday, 19th June, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:05 am

Soundbuy Morning

Post Trump's latest bit of ..... well, what is it? Protectionism? Belligerence? Playing to the crowd like he's on Price Is Right? I don't know.

doug43 Any broker comment on Capita about its dealings today?

BE11:11am

Here's Kit Juckes from SocGen.

FATDAZ morning all
BornCynic Yes - noticed China Mobile hit a new 52 week low and was thinking - how does that suffer in a trade war?
BE11:12am

USD 200bn of goods represents over a third of likely 2018 imports from China. For up to date analysis of this subject, The important point to note about the escalation, which will surely result in a Chinese response, is that while the tariffs imposed may be lower on the expanded range of goods, they will include more consumer goods, and therefore have a more direct impact on US consumers apart from anyone else. Away from the political implications, these tariffs will deliver higher prices to the US and weaker growth to China. In due course we will find out how Chinese policy-makers respond. Economics 101 suggests easier monetary policy and a weaker currency, but the Chinese preference for FX stability also needs to be taken into consideration. Either way, it’s a drag on growth on both sides of the Pacific. It decreases President Trump’s chances of making it to the next election before the US economy suffers a meaningful slowdown.

Dec69 - Skeptic Morning FDAZ.
Tom Dalgleish BC, is to do with the ZTE shakedown?
BE11:13am

Oh, and I've just realised we forgot a picture again.

FATDAZ on the subject of notes UBS has a v interesting note out about Dev Economies and flags a sharp slowdown outside of the US which its models suggest could be more than temporary dip.

Pharma @FATDAZ we are getting to the point where analysis seems to assume that constant growth is normal. Why are people always surprised by recessions?

On the later, Unite overnight announced that Capita's won the much-delayed Defence Fire Risk Management Organisation deal.

Golly Galoshes It will take a President of no small level of skill to manage an economy on the bubble, a trade war vs the world's 2nd biggest economy AND with the two geographic neighbours, and a domestic 'culture war' and random attacks on best friends like Germany and the UK all at the same time.
BE11:19am

Which is good for revenue -- £500m-ish converted from the pipeline -- and also good for confidence since they beat Rupert Soames' Serco.

Soundbuy @GG - he has 'no small level of skill'.............
FATDAZ have shared
11:20 am
BE11:20am

Course, winning government business usually means wearing a big loss in the first few years before you figure out whether you've underbid, but if you're concerned about that kind of thing then services sector's probably not for you.

BE11:20am

Here's UBS.

Pharma @FATDAZ a good reason to get my LR access reinstated. Lost it in an e-mail change.
BE11:21am

In a generally sluggish market, this has been a significant tender opportunity that both Capita and Serco were bidding for (Babcock pulled out of bidding in 2016), albeit one that was subject to repeated delays. We believe that this contract was in the bid pipeline of both Capita and Serco at c£500m, implying potential for c£50m p.a. in revenues i.e. +1-2% to group sales. While Capita have acknowledged the contract win, they have not provided any more detail at this stage. This contract win was not reflected in our forecasts for either Capita or Serco.

hornblower echo the call for Ashtead

BE11:22am

pancakes or waffles @Soundbuy @golly small hands though

BE11:24am

There endeth Capita.

FY earnings miss consensus by a we bit, no change to guidance, shares turn south.

Ashtead Group PLC (AHT:LSE): Last: 2,241, down 131 (-5.52%), High: 2,254, Low: 2,175, Volume: 2.43m
Timmmmmmmyyyyyy Inmarsat please! Bloomberg scoop yesterday - any views on that? Thank you
Pharma @FATDAZ, ooh, ta very much.
BE11:26am

JP Morgan Caz has the fullest explanation of the many moving parts.

BE11:27am

Ashtead’s Q4’18 results beat consensus (company compiled) at revenue but missed JPMe; at the earnings lines, the results are below JPMe/consensus. The weaker performance versus our model was primarily in A-Plant, which looks to have seen a slower end to the year, and Canada where we do not yet have a good handle on the moving parts given the limited history. Sunbelt was close to in line. Looking into FY19, the outlook points to 11-15% rental growth (8-11% organic and 3-4% from bolt-ons), assuming a ~low-50%s drop-through (which the company has talked to previously but probably needs to substantiate given the Q3/Q4 has been lower) would imply that consensus would be largely unchanged though that also depends on FX assumptions in models given the slightly weaker recent Sterling/US Dollar rates over the past couple of months. The initial capex guide for FY19 is for a “similar level” as in FY18 which is in line with the previous guide and our model, as in previous years, we would expect a conservative guide at this time of the year with potential upside if the market is as supportive as guided. Bigger picture, and most importantly, the commentary remains positive on the outlook and the group’s position in its markets and the plan to deliver 15-20% EPS growth with bolt-ons/buy-backs is reconfirmed. First take, a miss and the likely lack of upgrades to FY19 forecasts may out some pressure on the share price this morning, a reaction that may not be helped by the stock’s recent strength. However, we expect a conference call/analyst presentation which will be important in reconfirming the outlook and providing confidence on future growth rates. Even after the run in the share price, the stock is still inexpensive given the expected growth rates.

Manxish Second the request for Inmarsat please
11:27 am
BE11:27am

Barclays also, since we're here.

BE11:27am

Actually, not Barclays. RBC.

BE11:28am

Another positive set of results, with group rental revenue up 21%, £386m of FCF generation (after £1.2bn of capital invested in the business) and net debt to EBITDA leverage of 1.6x (2017: 1.7x). Sunbelt delivered an EITDA margin of 49.7% (2017: 49.5%), average physical utilization was 72% (2014: 71%) with an ROI of 24% (2017: 22%). Encouragingly, current trading to date has been similarly positive. Overall, a good set of numbers and with Capex plans held at a similar level to last year, the group clearly has continued confidence in the market outlook. Whilst we do not expect any significant changes to consensus forecasts today (other than FX), we continue to believe upside risks to earnings remains.

FATDAZ @pharam most welcome
11:28 am
BE11:28am

The Ashtead share price continues to perform well (+19% relative FTSE100 YTD), but on a CY19E PE rating of 13.5x (EV/EBITA 11x), the market clearly remains nervous of the cycle. Today’s statement should reassure in terms of both the underlying market growth trajectory and also supportive rate environment. With Canada set to pick up after the significant integration costs in Q4, a focus on the bottom line in the UK and the Sunbelt outlook remaining very strong, the group looks to have another positive platform going into FY19. We therefore reiterate our Outperform.

BE11:38am

ISAT has developed a leading position in the Mobile Satellite Service industry around an L-band satellite network. This was complemented by a kaband based hTS constellation, which provides more capacity and speed, and enabled ISAT to expand into new verticals. ISAT is also building a network composed of an S- band satellite service⁄LTE ground network to offer mobile broadband to airplanes in Europe. Also, ISAT leases L-band spectrum to Ligado for c. uSD0.13bn per year. Ligado is awaiting f¢¢ approval to repurpose this spectrum for terrestrial use. This process started more than ten years ago and is highly uncertain.

BE11:39am

What is Echostar interested in? Based on the current assets of Echostar and Inmarsat, it is hard to see any material synergies that could be generated by combining the two businesses. Also, we see our estimates for the stand-alone business as not particularly conservative. Echostar may be taking a view regarding the possibility of a Ligado request approval or on the underlying value of ISAT. FIe value the Ligado contract at gBp1, but it could be worth c. gBp3.4, i.e. a fair value of gBp6.6 for ISA.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Inmarsat in play? The press reported that Oneweb ‘talked’ to Inmarsat in 2017 before its unsuccessful attempt to combine with Intelsat (EFI). We note Echostar has a stake in Oneweb. We are skeptical ETL, SES or Viasat would be interested in acquiring Inmarsat.

Speaking of Barclays, someone mentioned Moneysupermarket earlier.

Moneysupermarket.Com Group PLC (MONY:LSE): Last: 304.00, down 19.1 (-5.91%), High: 322.00, Low: 297.40, Volume: 2.31m
Dec69 - Skeptic @BE the wifi services of aircraft is becoming rather crowded. So margins are going to be run harder. I think it's United is already driving a hard bargain. Maritime services aren't exactly loaded with high margin profits.
Excel Developer #China: Shanghai Composite maybe at a two year low but Fidelity China Special Situations (FCSS) is doing very well thanks (disclosure long)
BE11:41am

Barclays doing a bull-bear thing on Open Banking and mortgage broking .....

BE11:42am

The upshot of which is that the bear is a lot bigger than the bull. Price comparison might struggle once open banking comes along and does to banking what open broadband did to retention rates at TalkTalk, Plusnet and the like.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Relative to the fTSE All Share, Moneysupermarket’S 19x p⁄E is back to the level pre the new CEO announcing more investment in early March. Bulls argue this is still a model with structural growth, defensible margins and good cash characteristics, so have bought the dip. Is that merited? 19x is only cheap if EpS growth returns to double digits in our view. Leveraging multiple conversations with industry participants, in this note we delve into two new parts of the strategy: Open Banking and mortgages. We also review current end-market trends in the core product verticals. We believe the comparison landscape is changing, so forecasting mid-term growth is difficult. With good execution, we think a return to double-digit growth is possible (upside of 420p). But there is also a scenario where those days are gone, in which case the stock is overvalued (downside 250p). Nearer-term, investors look for an acceleration of growth in 2019 as a catalyst after a subdued 2018 – but weakening end-markets and more investment are potential headwinds. We stay EW, 310p pT (was 315p), until we get more visibility on execution. We prefer OW-rated Delivery hero and AutoTrader.

BE11:45am

You have to head into the note -- 59 pages! -- for the good stuff.

BE11:45am

Such as ......

Pharma Wonder if all 59 pages are such a testament to the numbing power of management-speak. That paragraph contained some corkers.
P thanks re MONY
11:46 am
BE11:46am

We believe that the direct comparison market could be about to start losing share. We think Open Banking is one step that will facilitate a fragmentation of the traditional price comparison audience between traditional price comparison services, banking apps, personal finance tools and other services that haven't yet been developed. The number of switches should be notably higher than today in, say, five years from now,
but it is hard to say how many of these switches will be done on price comparison apps vs third parties. FFenture ¢apital firms have been investing heavily in this space and it isn’t clear what the winning platform is going to be. In general, it isn’t positive when internet companies lose engagement of their customers though, and we see a risk of that happening in price comparison.

OJatHome Any thoughts on Koovs?
Dec69 - Skeptic Comparison market is always at risk from White label solutions. Its not hard to enter the market for say $1m.
Pharma #Open banking. People expressed outrage that their social media posts were being used to profile them. But they'll be perfectly happy for all their financial information to be added to the mix??(short answer: of course they will)
BE11:49am

Accordingly it makes total sense that Moneysupermarket is building out its B2B product to power switches on third-party apps as the audience fragments. But the unit economics of a B2C switch on the
Moneysupermarket platform are different to a B2B switch on a third-party platform. We think the absolute gross profit per switch is lower on a B2B switch. And over time there is the risk that a loss of audience engagement and lack of differentiation on technology drive down pricing in B2B. To what degree these B2B switches are cannibalistic or incremental is the key. We also lack visibility on whether market share dynamics will change in the B2B world – there is some risk of disintermediation by new white-LABEL PRODUCTS THAT DON’T RELY ON COMPARISON ENGINES AS well other comparison competitors in the space, which is still very dynamic. Even if they appear well positioned, wE NEED SOME MORE EVIDENCE TO ASSESS HOW Moneysupermarket's share might look in this B2B space and those conversations are just starting now. They WON’T REALLY PUSH AT THIS UNTIL THE dECISION tECHNOLOGIES DEAL (HOPEFULLY) CLOSES IN aUGUST. bUT THEY AREN’T FIRST TO THE space here.

Otter Hello friends
11:54 am
BE11:54am

UBS can summarise where we are.

FATDAZ @BE a reply to me just disappeared from the chat ?
BE11:54am

DEB has flagged that the expected recovery in H2 sales against weak comps has failed to materialise. Lower footfall remains the main problem. Trading in May and early June has been below plan and the market more promotional. Group LFL sales are down 1.7% in the first 15 weeks to H2 (UBSe +0.8%). FY gross margin guidance is also now down 150bp (from down 100bp), although there is some opex offset with costs now expected to be flat (from 0 to +1%). Gross margin guidance clips c£15m off PBT, with opex adding back c£6m. The remainder of the miss is from lower sales.

BE11:54am

There are no covenants on the £200m five-year bond, but there are on the £320m RCF. One of these is fixed charge cover, where management stated on the 4 January call that the covenant is little different from the 1.6x figure in the 2009 funding round. In our last note (see "Escalating tensions, Reiterate Sell", 12 February), we calculated that EBIT of £40-45m would present difficulties. This was based on EBITDAR / (rent + interest) with depreciation £110m, rent £220m and interest £11m. On the call today, DEB suggested that PBT of just under £20m would still be compliant, suggesting EBIT of c£30m is the floor. This may be a function of higher expected D&A and some sublet income. However, given pressure on the business, DEB has announced lower capex in FY19, a further focus on cost savings, and a strategic review of non-core assets.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

DEB believes that it has maintained share in apparel, although it may have needed to promote more aggressively to do so. Kantar data also only runs to early May. The reported period does include the snow in March, and the very wet early Easter, although since then trading should have recovered (see last four weeks of Next Q1 to early May, and the weather since then has been supportive). There is potentially a footfall / channel shift issue which gives Next and pureplay online retailers greater protection than others. If the issue really is channel shift, DEB is making some progress with digital sales +16% in Q3, although to sustain this, further investment in service levels may be required over the medium term.
